title: Week 1: December 29–January 4 - Introduction to the Old Testament

script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I have a question that's puzzled people for years. Why did the Jews try to stone Jesus just for saying three simple words: 'Before Abraham was, I am'? What was so shocking about that?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's a great hook, David. Those words directly echo what God told Moses at the burning bush in Exodus 3:13–15. Jesus was claiming to be Jehovah, the God of the Old Testament.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, so Jesus is Jehovah? That changes everything I thought I knew about the Old Testament.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. President Dallin H. Oaks taught that the scriptural records of words spoken by 'God' or the 'Lord' are almost always the words of Jehovah, our risen Lord, Jesus Christ. From the ancient Israelite perspective, Jehovah was their God who delivered them from Egypt and gave the law.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Fascinating. But from Christ's view, He's revealing His eternal identity. How does the restoration make this plain?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In the restoration, we see it clearly. The Father introduced the Son as our Savior, but Jehovah's voice in the Old Testament is Christ's. The Joseph Smith Translation and other revelations restore these plain and precious truths.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let's trace this Jehovah theme. Start with Exodus—God says to Moses, 'I AM THAT I AM.' Then Jesus says 'I am' and they pick up stones.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and notice the pattern across dispensations. In Moses 6:63, the Lord says all things bear record of Him. Jehovah appears to Adam, to Abraham, and speaks through prophets.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Hold on, so every time we read 'the Lord spake,' it's Jesus? That's profound.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Now, look at symbols that testify of Him right from the start. Take manna in Exodus 16:4, 11–15—the bread from heaven. Jesus calls Himself the Bread of Life in John 6:35.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I see it! Manna sustained Israel daily, pointing to Christ sustaining us spiritually.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And it continues: the sacrificial lamb in Exodus 12:3–5 foreshadows the Lamb of God in John 1:29. Then the brass serpent in Numbers 21:4–10, which Jesus references in John 3:14.

script.speaker: David
script.text: The pattern is everywhere. What about Jonah? Jonah 1:4–17 parallels Matthew 12:38–41.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Spot on. Jonah in the fish for three days mirrors Christ's resurrection. These aren't coincidences—they're divine patterns pointing to the Savior across time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: For historical context, ancient Israel saw these as literal miracles from Jehovah. What made them feel so immediate back then?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Imagine wilderness survival—manna appearing each morning was God's covenant provision. Archaeologically, we know manna-like substances exist, but this was miraculous, tied to obedience, much like our sacrament today.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's remarkable. So the mystery resolves: Jesus' 'I am' wasn't blasphemy—it was truth. He was Jehovah all along.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes! The Jews understood Exodus 6:3–5, where God says He appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but to Moses as Jehovah. Jesus unites it all.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Now, hidden connections: Nephi saw plain and precious things removed from the Bible in 1 Nephi 13:21–29. The Book of Moses restores Enoch's Zion in Moses 7:18–19.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And Abraham's council in heaven, Abraham 3:22–28. These show Jehovah's role in the premortal plan, linking Old Testament to our covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Covenants! The Old Testament is God making us His 'peculiar treasure' in Exodus 19:5.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Right, the everlasting covenant to prophets like Abraham. President Russell M. Nelson teaches it brings special love and mercy as we keep it.

script.speaker: David
script.text: How does this apply today? These symbols make the plan of salvation vivid.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Elder Dale G. Renlund urges us to focus on Jesus Christ as the treasure. In the Old Testament, we see Him in every page, strengthening our covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This year, as we study, we'll uncover more. Notice these patterns in your reading.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Start by asking: How does this testify of Christ? It transforms the ancient words into personal light, like Psalm 119:105—'Thy word is a lamp unto my feet.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. Listeners, dive into the Old Testament this week—look for Jehovah, the symbols, the covenants. You won't see it the same way again.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Can't wait to explore more together. God bless your study.
